posts.post_content:
@ Pago-Pago:  
Please don't give answers if you're not sure yourself. Both you and Guest are wrong. Your opponents CAN target the Troll in any zone other than play (or, as it is called now, the battlefield). Posted By: True_Mumin (6/15/2009 5:49:20 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Awesome card for enchanting since its not as likely to be removed. Two quick notes for some of the other posters here, a creature card not on the field is the same as a creature summoning spell, its flavor wise not the actual creature until its been summoned and in play, so yes your troll can be discarded or targeted from graveyard and library. Also, your opponent can still target and destroy enchantments and equipments your troll is enchanted with, but at least you aren't losing more than 1 card per their 1 removal card, versus if the creature was removed its 2 for 1 in your opponents favor. Enchant this guy with death touch for pure awesomeness, he comes with regeneration, and he can't die from very many spells, so your opponent has to deal with a regenerating blocker that kills their creatures.
posts.html:

Also, your opponent can still target and destroy enchantments and equipments your troll is enchanted with, but at least you aren't losing more than 1 card per their 1 removal card, versus if the creature was removed its 2 for 1 in your opponents favor. Enchant this guy with death touch for pure awesomeness, he comes with regeneration, and he can't die from very many spells, so your opponent has to deal with a regenerating blocker that kills their creatures.

posts.post_content:
Your opponent can still target it in your graveyard/hand/RFG zone...  
  
As long as it's in play though, it cannot be targeted.  
  
And the second part of your explanation is correct. It has to be in play for it to not be targeted, which is why Troll Ascetic can be countered. It's still amazing though.
posts.html:
Your opponent can still target it in your graveyard/hand/RFG zone...

posts.post_content:
That's indeed a nice weenie. widely protected from your opponents while you still get to boost this guy, decent regeneration and a tough body for three mana, that's what i call a fair trade :)  
It's certainly one of green's best three-drops, although i personally prefer [Kitchen Finks](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kitchen Finks).  
  
Well, he grew up at hard times back then in Mirrodin with [Ravager](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?multiverseid=50943) affinity, yet he still found use, the community labeled the ability he uses "troll-shroud" after all.  
  
Portal Three Kingdoms already made use of this ability on [Zuo Ci, the Mocking Sage](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Zuo Ci, the Mocking Sage) and [Taoist Hermit](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Taoist Hermit) back then, while [Plated Slagwurm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Plated Slagwurm) and the ascetic had it printed on them again in Mirrodin, which lets this appear to be a typical green ability, although several white cards make use of it these days as well.  
  
Both PTK cards didn't get famous at all, which might be the answer to your question, Keegan^^ "*hermit shr... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)*
posts.html:
That's indeed a nice weenie. widely protected from your opponents while you still get to boost this guy, decent regeneration and a tough body for three mana, that's what i call a fair trade :)
It's certainly one of green's best three-drops, although i personally prefer Kitchen Finks.

Well, he grew up at hard times back then in Mirrodin with Ravager affinity, yet he still found use, the community labeled the ability he uses "troll-shroud" after all.

Portal Three Kingdoms already made use of this ability on Zuo Ci, the Mocking Sage and Taoist Hermit back then, while Plated Slagwurm and the ascetic had it printed on them again in Mirrodin, which lets this appear to be a typical green ability, although several white cards make use of it these days as well.

Both PTK cards didn't get famous at all, which might be the answer to your question, Keegan^^ "hermit shr... (see all)

posts.post_content:
Question: The card says "Troll Ascetic" can't be the target ..... it doesn't say "This creature," which would imply it was in play. So can my opponent remove this card from my graveyard, or make me discard it from my hand? The text is referring to the card name itself, so I would \*\*\*ume it cannot be targeted in ANY zone by spells or abilities my opponent controls. Correct me if I'm wrong (for example, Shroud says in the comprehensive rules: "This permanent or player can’t be the target of spells or
  
abilities," which of course implies the card must be in play (for it to be a permanent)).
posts.html:
